hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the 3x3 grid. You need to identify all possible 2x2 squares within this grid. Remember, there are only a few positions where a 2x2 square can fit.
Consider how many cells in each 2x2 square need to be the same color for you to achieve your goal. A 2x2 square has 4 cells, so think about the combinations of colors you might encounter.
For each 2x2 square, count how many cells are 'B' and how many are 'W'. This will help you determine if you can convert one cell to make all cells the same color.
If a 2x2 square already has all cells the same color, you can immediately return true. Think about how you can check this condition efficiently.
If a 2x2 square has three cells of one color and one cell of another, you can change the one different cell to match the others. Keep track of these counts as you analyze each square.
Make sure to check all possible 2x2 squares in the grid. There are only four possible starting positions for the top-left corner of a 2x2 square in a 3x3 grid.

As you iterate through the grid, consider using nested loops to access each 2x2 square. For example, you can loop through the first two rows and first two columns to access the top-left corner of each square.
When you find a 2x2 square, you can use a simple condition to check how many cells are the same. For example, if you find 3 'B's and 1 'W', you can change the 'W' to 'B'.
Remember to handle edge cases where the grid might already contain a valid 2x2 square. If you find one, you can immediately return true without further checks.
Finally, if you check all possible 2x2 squares and none can be made uniform by changing at most one cell, return false. Ensure your logic accounts for all squares before concluding.

questionNotes: The grid is always 3x3 in size.
You can only change at most one cell.
The characters in the grid are either 'B' or 'W'.
Return true if a uniform 2x2 square can be formed; otherwise, return false.
